choices.text: A biopsy will show a histologic finding of columnar to squamous metaplasia
It is a known precursor of carcinoma of the stomach
The most common location is the proximal (upper) third of the esophagus
It is a known precursor of adenocarcinoma of the esophagus

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a chronic history of heartburn and regurgitation undergoes an upper endoscopy. Biopsy of the distal esophagus shows the presence of columnar epithelium with goblet cells. Which of the following is true of Barrett esophagus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is a known precursor of adenocarcinoma of the esophagus

 

Option D:

 

Barrett esophagus is a complication of long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease and is a precursor to esophageal adenocarcinoma.

 

Barrett esophagus intestinal is columnar metaplasia of the esopha¬geal squamous epithelium (squamous–to-columnar). The columnar epithelium is often of the intestinal type with goblet cells. Barrett esophagus is a complication of long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease and is a precursor of esophageal adenocarcinoma. The most common location is in the distal (lower) third of the esophagus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. The biopsy shows squamous to columnar metaplasia, not the other way around.

 

Option B. Incorrect. Barrett esophagus is a known precursor of esophageal adenocarcinoma, not gastric carcinoma.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Barrett esophagus most commonly occurs in the distal (lower) third of the esophagus, not the proximal (upper) third.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett esophagus shows intestinal columnar metaplasia of the esophageal squamous epithelium. It is a precursor lesion to esophageal adenocarcinoma, commonly located in the distal third of the esophagus.

 

Important risk factors for esophageal adenocarcinoma include Barrett’s esophagus, GERD, obesity, Tobacco use and radiation exposure.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 762

choices.text: Mallory-Weiss tears
Zenker’s diverticulum
Schatzki rings
Traction diverticula

questions.text: A patient complains of pain in the upper portion of his neck on swallowing. He occasionally regurgitates undigested food shortly after eating. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of his problems?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zenker’s diverticulum

Option B:

  • Zenker's diverticulum: This is a pharyngoesophageal outpouching that occurs above the upper esophageal sphincter at a weak point in the pharyngeal musculature (Killian's triangle). It's called a "false" diverticulum because only the mucosal layer herniates through the muscle layer. Symptoms can include dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, aspiration, and halitosis.
  • This is the classic presentation of Zenker’s diverticulum, which is a false diverticulum formed by herniation of the mucosa at a point of weakness at the junction of the pharynx and esophagus in the posterior hypopharyn¬geal wall. It is also associated with halitosis, and if the diverticulum fills completely with food, it can cause dys¬phagia or obstruction of the esophagus.

Explanation:

Option A. Mallory-Weiss tears: These are longitudinal mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction or gastric cardia. They often occur after forceful or prolonged vomiting and can lead to hematemesis. Alcoholics or individuals with bulimia are at a higher risk for this condition due to repeated episodes of vomiting.

Option C. Schatzki rings: These are thin, circumferential, mucosal rings that occur at the squamocolumnar junction in the distal esophagus. They can cause intermittent dysphagia for solid foods and are often associated with a sliding hiatal hernia.

Option D. Traction diverticula: These are "true" diverticula involving all layers of the esophageal wall. They are typically located in the mid-esophagus and can be caused by pulling forces from outside the esophagus, such as from fibrosis in mediastinal lymph nodes.

Educational objective:

Zenker’s diverticulum is a false diverticulum formed by herniation of the mucosa at a point of weakness at the junction of the pharynx and esophagus in the posterior hypopharyn­geal wall.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /757

choices.text: Glossitis
Esophageal webs
Megaloblastic anemia
Esophageal dysphagia

questions.text: A 46-year-old female presents with dysphagia, especially with solid foods, and has noted a burning sensation in her tongue. She reports a history of fatigue and breathlessness on exertion. On examination, her tongue is smooth and atrophic, and laboratory tests reveal a microcytic anemia. Plummer-Vinson syndrome is characterized by all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Megaloblastic anemia

Option C:

Megaloblastic anemia: Incorrectly associated. Plummer-Vinson syndrome is associated with iron-deficiency anemia, not megaloblastic anemia (which is typically due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency).

Explanation:

Option A. Glossitis: Correctly associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome, representing the smooth, atrophic tongue observed in this patient.

Option B. Esophageal webs: Also correctly associated, potentially explaining the patient's dysphagia for solids.

Option D. Esophageal dysphagia: Correctly associated, as this symptom is often due to esophageal webs or strictures present in Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

Educational Objective:

The clinical features of Plummer-Vinson syndrome, include glossitis, iron-deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs, and differentiate it from megaloblastic anemia.

Plummer-Vinson syndrome, also known as Paterson-Brown-Kelly syndrome, is characterized by the triad of glossitis, iron-deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs. So, the correct answer is (c) Megaloblastic anemia.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/757

choices.text: Achalasia
Barrett’s esophagus
Hiatal hernia
Plummer-Vinson syndrome

questions.text: A female with chronic dysphagia undergoes an upper endoscopy that reveals massive dilation of the distal esophagus. The esophagus is kinked and tortuous and partly filled with undigested foods. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achalasia

 

Option A:

 

Achalasia: Correct. Achalasia is defined by impaired esophageal motility and relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter, causing food accumulation and dilation of the esophagus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Barrett’s Esophagus: Incorrect for this scenario. Barrett’s esophagus involves the replacement of the lower esophageal squamous epithelium with columnar epithelium and is associated with chronic GERD, not presenting with significant dilation and kinking as described.

 

Option C. Hiatal Hernia: Incorrect. A hiatal hernia occurs when a portion of the stomach protrudes through the diaphragm into the chest cavity. While it can cause reflux and some degree of dysphagia, it typically doesn't result in the massive dilation and tortuosity of the esophagus.

 

Option D. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome: Incorrect. Plummer-Vinson syndrome is associated with iron-deficiency anemia, glossitis, and esophageal webs. It does not present with the dilation and tortuosity as described in the vignette.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Characteristic presentation of achalasia includes chronic dysphagia, dilation, and tortuosity of the esophagus, often with retained food material, which is distinguishable from other conditions such as Barrett's esophagus, hiatal hernia, and Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

 

Symptoms: Progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids, regurgitation of undigested food, weight loss, sometimes chest pain.

 

Imaging (Barium swallow): “Bird-beak” appearance

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 757

choices.text: Intestinal dysplasia
Intestinal columnar metaplasia
Simple columnar cell metaplasia
Columnar cell dysplasia

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a long history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) undergoes an upper endoscopy. Biopsy of the distal esophagus shows a change in the normal lining. Which of the following best characterizes Barrett’s esophagus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intestinal columnar metaplasia

 

Option B:

 

Intestinal columnar  metaplasia This is the correct answer. Barrett's esophagus is characterized by intestinal columnar metaplasia, where the normal stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced with columnar epithelium containing goblet cells, as a response to chronic acid reflux.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Intestinal dysplasia: This refers to precancerous changes within intestinal epithelium, which is not the finding typically associated with Barrett's esophagus. Dysplasia in Barrett’s esophagus is an important marker for the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma but not the characteristic feature of Barrett's itself.

 

Option C. Simple columnar cell metaplasia: While Barrett's esophagus does involve a change to columnar epithelium, the specific subtype with goblet cells is intestinal metaplasia, making this option incomplete.

 

Option D. Columnar cell dysplasia: This would imply a precancerous change in the columnar cells, which is not indicated solely by the presence of Barrett’s esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett's esophagus is characterized by intestinal columnar metaplasia, a histopathological change where the normal squamous epithelium of the lower esophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium containing goblet cells, secondary to chronic GERD. This condition necessitates surveillance due to the increased risk of progression to esophageal adenocarcinoma.

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 757

choices.text: Edge of ulcer
Base of ulcer
Adjacent indurated area around ulcer
Surrounding normal mucosa

questions.text: Best site for taking biopsy for viral esophagitis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Edge of ulcer

 

Option A:

 

Edge of ulcer: This is the best site for biopsy in the case of Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) esophagitis because the active virus tends to be located at the growing margin of the ulcer. Viral cytopathic action is most likely seen.

 

For diagnosis, the biopsy should be taken from edge of ulcer in HSV and base of ulcer in CMV.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Base of ulcer: This site is preferred for Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections. CMV infects the endothelial and stromal cells, and these infected cells are usually found at the base of the ulcer.

 

Option C. Adjacent indurated area around ulcer: While it can be important to rule out malignancy or to assess for other inflammatory processes, this area may not yield the specific viral inclusions or affected cells needed for a definitive viral diagnosis.

 

Option D. Surrounding normal mucosa: Sampling the normal mucosa is typically not helpful in diagnosing viral esophagitis because the characteristic histologic changes are seen in the affected tissue, not in the normal mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When suspecting viral esophagitis, it is imperative to biopsy the edge of the ulcer for HSV and the base of the ulcer for CMV to increase the likelihood of an accurate diagnosis. This targeted approach leverages the pathophysiological differences in how these viruses affect the esophageal tissue, thereby facilitating appropriate treatment.

choices.text: Majority of patients have associated atopic conditions
Feline esophagus is an endoscopic finding
Treatment of choice is high dose proton pump inhibitors
May be associated with food products like cow's milk and soy products

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Treatment of choice is high dose proton pump inhibitors

 

Option C:

 

The mainstay of treatment for EoE involves dietary modifications to eliminate food allergens and the use of topical steroids to reduce eosinophilic inflammation, not high-dose PPIs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Patients with EoE frequently have concurrent atopic conditions, which is a helpful clue in the diagnosis of this condition.

 

Option B. Feline esophagus is a term used to describe the ringed appearance of the esophagus seen during endoscopy in patients with EoE.

 

Option D. Food allergens such as cow's milk and soy are often implicated in EoE, and dietary elimination of these can be part of the management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incorrect statement is (c). The treatment of choice for eosinophilic esophagitis is not high-dose proton pump inhibitors but rather dietary modifications and steroids.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 760

choices.text: Mediastinal fibrosis
Diverticula
Caustic alkali burn
HPV

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents to the clinic with progressive dysphagia, unintentional weight loss, and odynophagia. He has a history of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and has been a heavy smoker and alcohol consumer for the past 30 years. Endoscopy reveals a suspicious lesion in the lower esophagus, and biopsy confirms the presence of squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following is NOT a recognized predisposing factor for the development of esophageal cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mediastinal fibrosis

Option A:

Mediastinal fibrosis: This is the correct answer. While mediastinal fibrosis can have various impacts on mediastinal structures, it is not directly implicated as a risk factor for esophageal cancer.

Explanation:

Option B. Esophageal diverticula: These outpouchings of the esophageal lining are associated with chronic irritation and inflammation, which can predispose to squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

Option C. History of caustic alkali burn: Ingestion of caustic substances leads to chronic esophageal injury and strictures, which increases the risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma.

Option D. Human Papillomavirus (HPV): HPV DNA is found more frequently in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma in regions with a high incidence of this cancer, suggesting a role in its pathogenesis.

Educational Objective:

While mediastinal fibrosis may have significant clinical consequences, it is not a risk factor for esophageal cancer. Risk factors for esophageal squamous cell carcinoma include caustic substance ingestion, chronic conditions like achalasia and bulimia, genetic conditions such as tylosis, nutritional deficiencies leading to conditions like Plummer-Vinson syndrome, exposure to external beam radiation, and HPV infection.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/764

choices.text: Chronic smoking
Alcohol
Reflux disease
Increased intake of spices

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with symptoms of heartburn, regurgitation, and dysphagia, particularly after meals and when lying down. Endoscopic examination reveals inflammation of the esophageal mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reflux disease

Option C:

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): This is the correct answer. GERD is the most common cause of esophagitis, as stomach acid refluxing into the esophagus leads to mucosal damage.

Explanation:

Option A. Chronic smoking: Smoking can worsen reflux symptoms by relaxing the lower esophageal sphincter, but it is not the most common direct cause of esophagitis.

Option B. Excessive alcohol consumption: While alcohol can irritate the esophageal lining and worsen symptoms in patients with GERD, it is not the primary cause of esophagitis.

Option D. Habitual consumption of highly spiced foods: Spicy foods can exacerbate symptoms of heartburn and reflux, but are not the primary etiological factor for esophagitis.

Educational Objective:

The primary cause of esophagitis is the reflux of gastric contents into the lower esophagus, typically due to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which results in inflammation and irritation of the esophageal lining. Understanding the etiology is essential for the appropriate management of esophagitis.

Direct line from Robbins

“Reflux of gastric contents into the lower esophagus is the most important cause of esophagitis”

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ e p759
